```{r, echo=FALSE}
library(shiny)
library(rmarkdown)
library(plotly)
library(iconr)
library(dplyr)
library(sf)
library(igraph)
dataDir <- system.file("extdata", package = "iconr")
imgs_path <- paste0(dataDir, "/imgs.csv")
imgs <- read.table(imgs_path, sep = ";", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
nodes_path <- paste0(dataDir, "/nodes.shp")
nodes.shp <- st_read(nodes_path, quiet = T)
nodes <- as.data.frame(nodes.shp)
edges_path <- paste0(dataDir, "/edges.shp")
edges.shp <- st_read(edges_path, quiet = T)
edges <- as.data.frame(edges.shp)
grph <- list_dec(imgs, nodes, edges)
lgrph <- list_dec(imgs, nodes, edges)
```

## Mrgin the legend


```{r fig-marginn, fig.margin = TRUE, fig.cap = "MPG vs horsepower, colored by transmission.", cache=TRUE, message=FALSE}
#| cap-location: margin
#| fig-cap: "dwdwwdwdwwddwwwdwdwdwddw"

library(ggplot2)
mtcars2 <- mtcars
mtcars2$am <- factor(
  mtcars$am, labels = c('automatic', 'manual')
)
ggplot(mtcars2, aes(hp, mpg, color = am)) +
  geom_point() + geom_smooth() +
  theme(legend.position = 'bottom')
```


## Arbitrary Full Width Content

Any content can span to the full width of the page. This feature requires Pandoc 2.0 or above. All you need is to put your content in a fenced `Div` with the class `fullwidth`, e.g.,

```md
::: {.fullwidth}
Any _full width_ content here.
:::
```

## Full Width Figures

You can arrange for figures to span across the entire page by using the chunk option `fig.fullwidth = TRUE`.

```{r fig-fullwidth, fig.width = 13, fig.height = 2, fig.fullwidth = TRUE, fig.cap = "A full width figure.", warning=FALSE, message=FALSE, cache=TRUE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price)) + geom_smooth() +
  facet_grid(~ cut)
```

## Full that thing

```{r fig.fullwidth = TRUE}
ggplot(diamonds, aes(carat, price)) + geom_smooth() +
  facet_grid(~ cut)
```
